Here I am at last! What a plaguy parcel of turnings and windings, to get up to this old crazy gallery! umph! It has made me as giddy as a goose. Now for my masters—Damn my masters! Scamper! Scamper! Scamper!—Twon't do—No; never fit for me. Give me a regular, steady, sober family for my money. If it hadn't been for the lanthorn I begg'd of the old boy at the Inn—I was forc'd to treat the drunken scoundrel before he would give it me—I might have tumbled over the bannisters. Mr. Random, now I think on't, ordered me to come in the dark! Umph! Gentlemen make no more of servants', necks now-a-days—they think we've one to spare, like the Swan in Lad-lane, I believe. But softly! softly! No noise. I must go to the chamber to tell him the carriage is ready. Let me see—it's the last door but one, at one end of the galiery; but whether it's to the right—or to the left,—curse me if I recollect. Stay—(Turning round, and counting the doors.) One—two—three.—Dam'me, how the doors dance! I shall never find the right, if they take it in their heads to run round so confoundedly. I remember, (Taking the chair, and drawing it along) when I lived with old Lady Hobble, she always sat still at Ranelagh to find out her company. Now, as these gentlemen here, (Pointing to the doors) chuse to take a Ranelagh round, I think I had better sit quiet in the middle of 'em, till my old acquaintance comes by. (Pulls the chair against the next door, and sits down.) Zounds! how fast somebody sleeps—Sir David, perhaps,—" if Baronets ever snore.
What the devil am I to do now? Get my head broke for not calling my master; and my bones broke, if I should happen to call any body else instead of him. As that is the case, I'll call no body, egad!—I'll e'en go back to the carriage, and wait till they come for me. So—gently—steady.—

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Once more every thing is quiet. I can't conceive who it could be so long with a light in the gallery.—I had best give Random notice of what has happen'd; that in case we are watch'd, he may be upon his guard. Hereabouts the door must be—(Going to the door, Random enter'd) Eh! no chair—'Sdeath, this is Sir David's! A pretty blunder I shou'd have made! (Goes to the next) O here it is at last. (Taps at the door.) What a number of accidents this little contrivance has prevented! I had better explain to him what has happen'd in the inside of my chamber; for it's dangerous waiting on the outside a moment, I find. What the deuce keeps him so long now?
SP.STAGE: (Sir David opens the door in his bed-gown and night-cap.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Well?

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Hush! it's I.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: I!

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Softly! Softly! Zounds, you are so unguarded! Follow me! Quick, quick! Only follow me, and you shall hear all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Follow me! Damn'd if I do tho'. Can't stir a step without running the risk of breaking my nose. Cursed queer! A fellow in the dark with no name—a rascal, to rob the house perhaps—Gad, it has put me all in a witter.
SP.STAGE: Random comes out with a bundle, from the Women's chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: St! St!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Eh!

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: 'Tis I.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: So! here's t'other I.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Where are you?. Here! hold th bundle. (Thrusting it into his hands.) Why what makes you shake so? Are you cold here?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Zounds, a thief!—He'll cut my throat if I cry out.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: For shame, flurried at such a trifle as this! But there's no knowing even one's friends till they're tried, I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: "Like enough." Most of your friends have been tried, I dare say.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: But we shall have a whole cargo to carry. Stay where you are now. Don't stir for your life, and I'll be back in an instant. We'll soon make an end, I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: That you will—a pretty public one too, I take it. Mercy on me! How shall I get away? The dog's given me a bundle here as big as a child. I shall be brought in for a new kind of burglary—Cast for breaking into my own house, and hang'd for robbing myself of my property. My Lady's lock'd up below, I suppose; bound back to back with the old house∣keeper: or gagg'd and ravish'd, poor quiet soul, with the rest of the family females. If I could but contrive to—

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Hollo!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Oh, the Devil! There's one in every corner—a whole banditti playing at bo∣peep.

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Come, come, don't trifle now; I've something to say to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: The fellow don't know me in the dark. I'll deceive him.

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Nay this delay will—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Hush.

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: What's the matter? Any body co∣ming?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Yes—Yes—

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Ha! We are discovered. In—In—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Now if I could but crawl down this back stair case.—
SP.STAGE: (Meets Random coming out, and runs against him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Now, my dear Scruple, all's ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Zounds, it's the two Merchants!

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Our packing is all over—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Our two fair ones both equipt for flight.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: My Harriet?—

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Yes, and my Kitty—They'll be in our arms in an instant, you rogue! And we've nothing to do, but to lead 'em to the coach, and away as fast as love, money, and horses can carry us. Did'nt I tell you now, that your doubts were all nonsense? but 'sdeath, you are so dull about it: your fears have so overcome you, that—why aren't you like me—All rapture, all pas∣sion?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Aye, this is right now! this is as it shou'd be. But I'll go and bring 'em out. (Going.)—(Turns back.) a! ha! ha! I can't help laughing to think what a damn'd clatter Sir David will make by and by.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: His fat fubsy wife too; cackling about the house, like an old hen that has lost her chickens.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: —Old Hen! “Dam'me, I wish she had never sat to have brought such a brood.”

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: And he too. Did you ever see such a tedious booby in your life?

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: But I'll go and conduct our charge. By the bye, has Tiptoe been here?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Careless scoundrel! But we shall find him at the gate with the carriage, I suppose. Now for it. Now to deliver our damsels from the clutches of an obstinate fool of a father. A blockhead, to think to marry women to whom he pleases! No, no: whenever there's any for∣bidden fruit, it is not in human nature to rest easy till it is tasted.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Liquorish dogs!

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Why, what cou'd he mean! There's no noise: all's quiet as can be.—Random.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Well!

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Are you ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Yes, yes; didn't I tell you so? We're coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Well, well! Tiptoe has not been here.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Pshaw! Plague, I know it; you told me so already.

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Did I? When?

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Why this instant; but you are in such a flutter, you can't remember a word you say. But you have taken care of the bundle, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Bundle! What bundle?

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: That, that I gave you just now.

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Just now! not you indeed! Why you're in a flutter yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Pooh! pooh! I tell you the bundle I brought out of the room. The bundle that—

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Damn the bundle! I never saw it, nor felt it in all my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Now how can you be so cursed obsti∣nate? I put it into your own hands, and you shook as if you'd an ague.

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Shook! your memory is shook, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Gad I cou'd have sworn I had given it you, but we must not stand upon trifles now.—Time's precious.—(Opens the Women's door—Harriet and Kitty come out.) This way, this way. Now, ladies, we attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Lud! it's as dark as pitch.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Never fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Heavens! how I tremble.

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Courage now, my Harriet, and we may soon defy every danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Well said, Courage! well said, Caesar, egad! 'Sdeath, madam, if you draw back now you spoil all. I'll bring you all thro' I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I fear I shall never bear up. The step I am taking, the weight on my spirits—

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Vapours! vapours, from being in the dark—nothing else, believe me, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: My mother too—What will not she feel?

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Nay, pursue this no farther.

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Mamma will be in a sweet bustle, I warrant. Rattling about Sir David's ears for bringing you into the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Be quiet, I know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Yes, that's exactly like him for all the world. Gemini, I shall never find my way.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Stay! take my arm. Come, madam.—Scruple—arm in arm all four, and then for our march.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: March! dam'me but I'll muster among ye tho'—
Sir David comes forward between them. Kitty takes hold of Sir David's and Random's arms—Harriet of Sir David's and Scruple's; all arm in arm, Sir David in the middle.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: So, thus link'd, he must be a cunning and a bold fellow too, that thinks of dividing us,

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Hark! somebody rings at the gate.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Oh mercy! we shall be seen.

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty
SP.P: Lud! there's a light! hide! hide us, for heaven's sake. It's mamma as sure as I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: (aloud.) No, no! stay where you are. Come along, my lady! a light will do us a deal of good.
Enter Lady Dunder, with a light.
Servant, ladies and gentlemen!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Mercy on me! Sir David! girls! gentlemen!

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Confusion!

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: Sir David!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Yes, here we are—been frisking about like a parcel of rabbits. Our burrows are all empty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Why what's the meaning of—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Be quiet—meaning? treachery—mean to bamboozle us—Dark night, rope lad∣ders, Garden gate, and Gretna Green—that's the meaning of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: How! and is this the return for—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P:
Hush! aye is this the return for
my open, hospitable, generous—I that put salt in your porridge, bread in your mouth, and steaks in your stomach; cramm'd every thing into you, but gratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: And came here on purpose I suppose with a trump'd-up story of—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Trump! dam'me, this will be their last trump I take it. And you too! (to the wo∣men) You! (to Harriet) you that I intended to link to a lord; to go and give up a peer for a pedlar! a merchant! a fellow here that lives like a lobster by salt water; a culler of pepper and spice; a trader in train oil, Greenland blubber, and China pipkins; or a black dealer in devils to sell at American markets.

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: 'Sdeath! What is all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: If you'll give us leave, sir, to—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Give! gad you'd have taken leave without asking—French leave if I had not been here; have smuggled my goods in the dark, trotted over the Tweed, and been hammer'd to∣gether by a bare-breech'd blacksmith. A fine Scotch union, egad! my two rich roses here tied to a pair of poor pitiful thistles! but zounds! I'll have satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: For heaven's sake, my dear!—cool your holer a little, Sir David.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Be quiet. What have I had a sword bobbing between my legs, at Dover hops, and quiet country meetings, for these twenty years; and now not rub off its rust, in the oily guts of a couple of whale catchers, for what I know to the contrary?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Rand.
SP.P: Come along, Carney! late as it is, my gentleman can't escape now, I believe. (They enter.) Hey-dey! the whole family col∣lected!

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: My father! a pretty business we have made of it!

SP.SPEAKER: Old Rand.
SP.P: I beg pardon for this intrusion—but if Sir David Dunder is here, and sees the occasion—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: I know it: see it all, already: fine occasion indeed: and you too—(to Old Rand.) act as accomplices, do you?—an old fellow—sham? What you've a wig, now, I warrant, like a young counsellor's—squeez'd over a toupee with a dap∣per tail peeping out between the tyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Rand.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: My worthy old friend means, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Hush—He is an old one, is he? means to run away with my wife, then, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I fancy he'd find it a difficult matter to carry me off.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Rand.
SP.P: Run away! Not I. I came here after a couple of youngsters, that—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Did you? There they are. Take 'em away with you: as pretty a pair as any in England: you may match 'em against all Europe, egad.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Rand.
SP.P: So, you are two pretty gentle∣men; are not you? And how dare you, Sir, look me in the face, after your proigate proceedings? (To Random.) Not content neither in contracting debts, but you must have me, your poor ather, you dog, arrested for 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Carn.
SP.P: Yes, and me too.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: I am at a loss how to comprehend, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Old Rand.
SP.P: But that rascal, that rogue, Roundfee, I think they call him, he can, I be∣lieve. Here have I and poor Carney just been taken into custody for you at Dover; while you have been playing your pranks at large all over the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Eh! be quiet—Cursed ungenteel though in you, if you are his father. Why, Zounds! you have us'd me worse than they! Get yourself lock'd up for your son here, with a plague to you! that he and his friend may have time to run off with my daughters.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Rand.
SP.P: I! I have withdrawn my counte∣nace long ago, I promise you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Ha! family failing. The son would have withdrawn his countenance too, if I'd let him.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Rand.
SP.P: How! what, attempt to—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Be quiet.—I am the injured party: let me speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: No, Sir David, I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: To end all confusion, I'll speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: What the deuce can Doubtful say now, after all?

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: It is yourself, Sir David, who have been chiefly to blame.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Eh!

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: He beats me all to nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Scrup.
SP.P: Your unguarded kindness to strangers might have been attended with much more dis∣agreeable consequences. You took our charac∣ters from report, I see. Characters which we never thought of assuming.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Oh! Damn Paul!

P.Q:
“Our invitation was unsought: and
though our manner of requiting your favours appears unjustifiable, you may congratulate yourself, that instead of being practis'd upon by men, unworthy your countenance, you have met with gentlemen.”
“Here's two fine fellows! come into my house—going to carry off half on't on their shoulders—and then—I have met with gentlemen.”

SP.SPEAKER: Scruple.
SP.P: Our conduct, Sir David, is not so culpable as you imagine. A chance, like your present invitation, threw us in your daughters' way at Bath, and our continued affection (I think I may answer for my friend) may prove our mo∣tives are unguided by interest: as a further proof of it, we disclaim all views of their fortune.—Bestow but their hands, Sir David, and we shall be happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir David.
SP.P: Eh! Zounds! something noble in that too.

P.Q: “But to think of carrying away our two dear rosy girls here; handsomer than all” the pale chits of the county.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dav.
SP.P: Hush! handsomer! Ay, and richer “too! with pockets full of money: housewives stuff'd with bank notes; and work bags cramm'd with guineas.”

SP.SPEAKER: Old Rand.
SP.P: Indeed, I begin to think Dick is not such a sad dog as I took him for. Eh! Carncy?

SP.SPEAKER: Carn.
SP.P: I am perfectly of your opinion, Mr. Random.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: And what has the other gentleman to say for himself?

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Indeed, Mamma, we are not so much to blame, neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P:
Love, Madam, all powerful love, must plead my excuse; a passion which may
once have influenc'd your Ladyship's delicate, susceptible bosom.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Well, I vow the young man pleads so prettily in his defence that—

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: If your ladyship and my father could forget past occurrences, and join with me in my suit to Sir David for an union with his daugh∣ter—I hope my future conduct—

SP.SPEAKER: Old Rand.
SP.P: Um!—Why, as things are so, Sir David; and my connections are pretty con∣siderable—my estate pretty well known—

SP.SPEAKER: Carn.
SP.P: A good six thousand a year—I have known my good friend here some time; and have had his property under my eye, for these five years.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Rand.
SP.P: And his friend, I am happy to tell you, is as well connected as he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir David.
SP.P: Is he? Well, as matters are—and as my Lord might find a flaw here—an ugly business, not much to his liking—I think we can but in honour be off—so to prevent cursed country scandal, gabbling girls, ugly old maids, and all that—I think we may as well—my Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: As you think proper, Sir David.—Harriet?

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: We are bound now, Madam, both by inclination and duty to follow your com∣mands.

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Yes, Mamma, we are both bound.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir David.
SP.P: Well then; there, there! take one another—no words.

SP.SPEAKER: Rand.
SP.P: And now, Kitty, I am your prisoner for life.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Rand.
SP.P: Remember, Roundfee, tho'—There you might have been a prisoner not much to your liking.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir David.
SP.P: What! a usurer! Dam'me, let's duck him.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Rand.
SP.P: Oh! he and his gentleman may be settled with at leisure. Their blunders have left them to our mercy, and they merit none, I promise you—Fellows whose business it is to prey upon the unthinking, extort from the needy, and live upon the distresses of mankind, deserve very little compassion, when they are distressed themselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir David.
SP.P: I know it.—But here, however, they shall have no distresses to prey upon—No moping melancholy looks now. All's well, I hope, at last, as it ought to be—and nothing ought to give any of us, here, so much pleasure as looking, to-night, on a set of very merry faces.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE,
DIV1.BYLINE: Written by the Author of the COMEDY.
DIV1.P: Speken by Mr. PALMER, in the Character of a News-Paper Writer. (Squabbling behind the Scenes.)
DIV1.L: I TELL you I must and will speak. How—not fit?
Pooh! prithee—I will but harangue 'em a bit. (comes forward)
Excuse me, good folks—I'm just popt from the Pit.
I'm a Critick, my masters! I sneer, splash and vapour:
Puff Party: Damn Poets: in short—Do a Paper.
My name's Johnny Grub—I'm a vender of Scandal,
My Pen, like an Auctioneer's Hammer, I handle;
Knocking down Reputations by one inch of candle!
I've heard out the Play: But I need not have come.
I'll tell you a secret, my masters—but, mum!
Tho' ramm'd in amongst you, to praise or to mock it,
I brought my Critique, cut and dry, in my pocket.
We, great, Paper Editors,—strange it appears!
Can often, believe me, dispense with our Ears.
The Athor—like all other Authors—well knowing
Tt W are the People to set him a-going,
begg'd me, just now, in a flattering tone,
a friendly Critique of his own.
good has its evil: We don't pay a Souse—
Neither We, nor our friends, to come into the House;
But then 'tis expected, because we are free,
We are bound to praise all the damn'd nonsense we see:
Hence comes it, the Houses, their emptiness scorning,
At low ebb at Night everflow in the Morning!
Hence Audiences, sated at ease, at the Play,
Are squeed to a mummy, poor devils, next day!
Even Actors themselves, will extort something from us;
And the vilest Performer's an Actor—of promise.
Whle self-praising Authors, write Volumes on Volumes,
And Puffs, every morning—like smoke—rise in columns!
Our Bard of to-night,—I had tickl'd him sweetly!
Foists his Puff upon me—damn it, mine was so neatly
Work'd up—it's a pity—an excellent Pill!
Some sweet—three Parts sour—shall I read it?—I will!
"Last night: Little Theatre: Comedy,—Name,
"Ways and Means—unproductive—Plot blind, Lang
"As the Author has Parts—Our Advice, in this Play,
"Is—New model the Story—but this by the way,
"His Dialogue too,—he may trust to Our Print,
"Is, tho' poor, gross and vulgar—but this is a hi▪
"Impartial's our Motto—There's really no end
"To his Puns and his Quibbles—We speak as a Friend▪
"That the Actors had doubts on't, we cannot help thi
"For they all did their utmost to keep it from sinking.
"Young Bannister bustled, in hopes of it's rising,
"And Palmer's exertions were really surprising."
So much for Ourselves.—What the Author advances,
To support Ways and Means, will ne'er mend his Finance
He calls it a light, Summer thing,—and, with, him,
His Pun is all Laugh,—and his Quibble all Whim—
In short his Critique would so tire you to hear it,
I must publish my own—or else something that's near
If therefore, in any one Paper you see
An abuse of the Play,—whatsoever it be,—
Wherever the Poet shall find a hard rub,
That Paper, depend on't, is done by—JOHN GRU▪
